did.head: Overview of the Collection
did.repository: Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center.
did.abstract: Joseph A[nthony] Smith, children's author/illustrator and artist received his BFA from the Pratt Institute in 1960, where he began teaching in 1961. He continues to teach there in the Department of Painting and Drawing. The collection contains artwork for over thirty children's books.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Joseph A[nthony] Smith was born in Bellefonte, Pennsylvania in 1936. He studied with Hobson Pittman at the Pennsylvania State University from 1955-1957 and received his BFA from the Pratt Institute in 1960, where he began teaching in 1961. He continues to teach there in the Department of Painting and Drawing.

Smith has also worked as a professional artist since 1961. He has exhibited his work at the Pennsylvania Academy for Fine Arts (1961, 1967, 1969), at the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences (1966), at the Bethel Gallery in Connecticut (1978), at the Newhouse Gallery in Staten Island (1982), at Adirondak Community College in New York ( 1987), at the Trenton City Museum (1992), at the Staemfli Gallery in New York (1992), at the Esther Allen Green Museum in Ohio, and at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center in Connecticut (2004). Though these exhibitions were independent, Smith has also worked extensively with other artists. Smith has also employed his art by working as a design consultant, an exhibition designer, and a member of the Board of Directors on the Staten Island Council of Arts (1971-1976).

Smith's art has been recognized by his peers with several prestigious awards, including the Mary S. Litt Award for Watercolor, 100th Annual American Watercolor Society (1967) and the New York Society of Illustrators Merit Award (1973, 1974, 1979, 1982, 1998).

p.bibref: Bunton, Donald, Jr., et al., Who's Who in American Art: 2001-2002, New Providence, New Jersey, Marquis Who's Who, 2001. 1116.

bibref.title: The Pen and Ink Book: Materials and Techniques for Today's Artist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Joseph A. Smith Papers contain work by and documents pertaining to Joseph A. (Jos. A.) Smith's career as an illustrator of children's books. The collection consists, in the main, of original artwork by Smith and color proofs. The contents of the collection date from roughly 1983 to 2002. The majority of the collection dates from the 1990s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Joseph A. Smith Papers contains only one series: Children's Literature. The collection does not include any of Joseph A. Smith's works in other genres at this time.

For ease of research, the collection is arranged alphabetically by book title. When necessary, there has been some separation of materials according to physical size. This separation is reflected in the finding aid by box numbers and locations.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Archives & Special Collections has a substantial collection of children's literature artwork and children's literature. For detailed information on these collections please contact the curator or ask at the reference desk.

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: This record series is indexed under the following controlled access subject terms.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: There are no access restrictions for this collection.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Permission to publish from these Papers must be obtained in writing from both the University of Connecticut Libraries and the owner(s) of the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item description, #:#], Joseph A. Smith Papers. Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The materials in this collection were received from Joseph A. Smith in three installments. The first and largest accession was received in 1997, and two smaller and later donations were received in 2001 and 2003.
